rev.diff:
Line 16: Line 16:
In some societies the practice was enacted owing to a belief that the soul of an unmarried woman would not find peace; among the [[Jingpo|Kachin]] of Myanmar and the Nambudri of India, versions of a marriage ceremony were held to lay a dead virgin to rest, which would involve intercourse with the corpse. Similar practices obtained in some pre-modern Central European societies when a woman who was engaged to be married died before the wedding.<ref>Walker, Benjamin. ''Encyclopaedia of Metaphysical Medicine'', Routledge 1978, pp. 191-2. Walker cites Rollo Ahmed, ''The Black Art'', John Long, London, 1936, in support.</ref>
In some societies the practice was enacted owing to a belief that the soul of an unmarried woman would not find peace; among the [[Jingpo|Kachin]] of Myanmar and the Nambudri of India, versions of a marriage ceremony were held to lay a dead virgin to rest, which would involve intercourse with the corpse. Similar practices obtained in some pre-modern Central European societies when a woman who was engaged to be married died before the wedding.<ref>Walker, Benjamin. ''Encyclopaedia of Metaphysical Medicine'', Routledge 1978, pp. 191-2. Walker cites Rollo Ahmed, ''The Black Art'', John Long, London, 1936, in support.</ref>

[[Guido Henckel von Donnersmarck]] (1830-1916) engaged in a form of thanatophilia following the death in 1884 of his first wife, the former [[courtesan]] Pauline ThÃ©rÃ¨ se de PaÃ¯va, better known as [[La PaÃ¯va]]. Her naked body was immersed in alcohol in an isolated room of Henckel's castle at [[Neudeck]] in [[Silesia]]. Henckel visited her corpse regularly for a strange sort of contemplation. It is said that when, several years after their marriage, Henckel's second wife unexpectedly discovered the body of her predecessor, preserved in all its glory in a glass tank of alcohol, she suffered a [[mental breakdown]].

[[Guido Henckel von Donnersmarck]] (1830-1916) engaged in a form of thanatophilia following the death in 1884 of his first wife, the former [[courtesan]] Pauline ThÃ©rÃ¨ se de PaÃ¯va, better known as [[La PaÃ¯va]]. Her naked body was immersed in alcohol in an isolated room of Henckel's castle at [[Neudeck]] in [[Silesia]]. Henckel visited her corpse regularly for a strange sort of contemplation. It is said that when, several years after their marriage, Henckel's second wife unexpectedly discovered the body of her predecessor, preserved in all its glory in a glass tank of alcohol, she suffered a [[mental breakdown]]. a necrophiliac is a pineaple farmer from ethiopia, who has magical powers to grow pineapples with his mind.
